definitions.definition: The direction opposed to the pull of gravity.
definitions.example: Up is a good way to go.
I hate almost everything about my job. The only up is that it's so close to home.

definitions.definition: An upstairs room of a two story house.
definitions.example: She lives in a two-up two-down.
If we up the volume, we may be able to hear what he says.
It wasn’t long before they upped him to Vice President.

definitions.definition: (usually in combination with another verb) To act suddenly.
definitions.example: He just upped and quit.
100 new apps and games have just been upped.
Put the notebook face up on the table.

definitions.definition: On or at a physically higher level.
definitions.example: The flood waters are up again across large areas of the country.

definitions.definition: Headed, or designated to go, upward, as an escalator, stairway, elevator etc.
definitions.example: Where is the up escalator?

definitions.definition: Fitted or fixed at a high or relatively high position, especially on a wall or ceiling.
definitions.example: The Christmas decorations are up.
The kite is up!
Don't go into the living room just now – I've got the carpet up.
Are the new buildings up yet?
The audience were up and on their feet.
I can’t believe it’s 3 a.m. and you’re still up.

definitions.definition: (of the sun or moon) Above the horizon, in the sky.
definitions.example: It'll get warmer once the sun's up.

definitions.definition: Larger; greater in quantity, volume, value etc.
definitions.example: My temperature is up this morning.

definitions.definition: Indicating a larger or higher quantity.
definitions.example: The barometer is up, so fine weather should be on the way.
The home team were up by two goals at half-time.
Is your new video up yet? I looked on the website, but I couldn't find it.
Her contract is up next month, so it's time to negotiate another one.
I’m feeling up today.

definitions.definition: (usually in the phrase up for) Willing; ready.
definitions.example: If you are up for a trip, let’s go.
Smith is up to bat.

definitions.definition: (not used attributively) Happening; new; of concern. See also what's up with.
definitions.example: What is up with that project at headquarters?

definitions.definition: (postnominal) Said of the higher-ranking pair in a two pair.
definitions.example: AAKK = aces up
I’m not up on the latest news. What’s going on?
Is the server back up?

definitions.definition: (of a railway line or train) Traveling towards a major terminus.
definitions.example: The London train is on the up line.
A Cosmopolitan is typically served up.

definitions.definition: Away from the surface of the Earth or other planet; in opposite direction to the downward pull of gravity.
definitions.example: I looked up and saw the airplane overhead.

definitions.definition: To or at a physically higher or more elevated position.
definitions.example: All day we climbed up and up.

definitions.definition: To a higher level of some quantity or notional quantity, such as price, volume, pitch, happiness, etc.
definitions.example: Cheer up, the weekend's almost here.

definitions.definition: To or in a position of equal advance or equality; not short of, back of, less advanced than, away from, etc.; usually followed by to or with.
definitions.example: A stranger came up and asked me for directions.

definitions.definition: (intensifier) Used as an aspect marker to indicate a completed action or state; thoroughly, completely.
definitions.example: Can you sum up your research?

definitions.definition: To or from one's possession or consideration.
definitions.example: I picked up some milk on the way home.
I live in Florida, but I'm going up to New York to visit my family this weekend.

definitions.definition: Towards or at a central place, or any place that is visualised as 'up' by virtue of local features or local convention, or arbitrarily, irrespective of direction or elevation change.
definitions.example: He lives up by the railway station.

definitions.definition: Towards the principal terminus, towards milepost zero.
Aside, so as not to be in use.
definitions.example: to lay up riches; put up your weapons

definitions.definition: (Cartesian graph) In a positive vertical direction.

definitions.example: The bowler pitched the ball up.
Would you like that drink up or on ice?

definitions.definition: (academia) To university, especially to Cambridge or Oxford.
definitions.example: She's going up to read Classics this September.
The cat climbed up the tree.

definitions.definition: Toward the center, source, or main point of reference; toward the end at which something is attached.
definitions.example: I felt something crawling up my arm.
We sailed up the East Coast of England from Ipswich to South Shields.
Go up the street until you see the sign.

definitions.definition: From the mouth towards the source of (a river or waterway).
definitions.example: He led an expedition up the Amazon.

definitions.definition: Of a man: having sex with.
definitions.example: Phwoar, look at that bird. I'd love to be up her.

definitions.definition: At (a given place, especially one imagined to be higher or more distant from a central location).
definitions.example: I'll see you later up the snooker club.
